cards.title: US Open Cup / Dempsey given two-year ban for tearing up ref's notebook
cards.rawTitle: Dempsey given two-year ban for tearing up ref's notebook

item.title: Clint Dempsey given two-year US Open Cup ban for tearing up ref's notebook
item.trailText: Former Tottenham striker Dempsey saw red in Seattle’s defeat against Portland and was punished for his confrontation with the referee
item.standFirst: Former Tottenham striker Dempsey saw red in Seattle’s defeat against Portland and was punished for his confrontation with the referee
item.body:
Seattle forward Clint Dempsey was handed a minimum two-year suspension from the US Open Cup on Thursday and a second fine for his conduct toward a referee in a game last week.

Related: Did Jürgen Klinsmann pick the right USA squad for the Gold Cup?

The penalty announced by a US Soccer Federation panel was in addition to a three-game league ban and fine announced last week by Major League Soccer.

The second penalty, issued by the US Open Cup adjudication and discipline panel, covers up to six US Open Cup matches. If the Sounders lose their initial match each year, the penalty would last through 2021.

Dempsey was punished for a confrontation with a ref on June 16 in the Sounders’ fourth-round loss to rival Portland, when he grabbed a notebook from the official and tore it after a teammate was given a red card.

The USSF said Dempsey waived his right to appeal.

displayImages.altText: Dempsey rips up referee Daniel Radford’s notebook.

headerImage.caption: Dempsey rips up referee Daniel Radford’s notebook. Photograph: Erika Schultz/AP

headerImage.cleanCaption: Dempsey rips up referee Daniel Radford’s notebook.

cards.title: England’s Chapman ready for mother of all battles against Canada
cards.rawTitle: England’s Chapman ready for mother of all battles against Canada

item.title: England’s Katie Chapman ready for mother of all battles against Canada
item.trailText: The Chelsea midfielder was treated to a surprise family reunion with her husband Mark and their three sons, but now her focus is only on beating Canada on Sunday, she tells Louise Taylor
item.standFirst: The Chelsea midfielder was treated to a surprise reunion with her husband and three sons, but now her focus is only on beating Canada on Sunday
item.body:
Katie Chapman is not merely England’s midfield enforcer but one of only two mothers in Mark Sampson’s squad. After spending five weeks with the side in Canada she acknowledges a certain conflict of loyalties as preparations for Sunday’s quarter-final against the host nation in Vancouver intensify.

It helps that her husband Mark, an electrician, surprised Chapman by flying out to Moncton – England’s base for their first two group games – with their three sons, 12-year-old Harvey, six-year-old Riley and two-year-old Zachary.

Related: Women's World Cup power rankings: Germany lead the way from Matildas

The brief visit was designed to celebrate Chapman’s 33rd birthday and Zachary’s second. “I had no clue whatsoever they were coming. When they turned up it was a massive surprise I just stood there and cried,” says the Chelsea midfielder. “Before the tournament we’d decided we couldn’t do it money wise. But Mark then decided we could! For me to come down and see them standing there was overwhelming. Mark sorted the finances and the flights off his own bat. It was so lovely to see my family.”

An indirect long-haul flight from London to Moncton with three children in economy cannot have been easy but her husband was determined to stage a double birthday reunion. “It was a massive task for him,” says Chapman. “I’m really proud of him but he’s a really hands-on Dad. He felt that strongly about wanting to bring them over to see me. I didn’t want to miss Zachary’s second birthday [on the day of the Mexico game] so that was a real bonus for me.

“I was able to see them that evening after beating Mexico and sing happy birthday to him. That was really lovely. If I’m away from the children for any length of time I miss them. I needed that. It was great to have that family time but then it was back to having a real focus on the tournament and getting on with the job.”

Not that a woman who was dropped from the squad by Hope Powell, Sampson’s predecessor, due to her family commitments, and temporarily lost her central contract with England, is entirely out of touch with events back home.

“FaceTime is a life saver,” she says. “I’ve been speaking to them quite a lot on the computer. But I’m finding being in Vancouver with the eight-hour time difference a bit tough. It’s quite weird. We got here on Tuesday night and then I had to try and catch them before they went to school . As they are getting up I’m going to bed.”

Chapman needs her sleep ahead of an occasion she hopes will make all her sacrifices worthwhile. “It’s going to be an absolutely massive game, maybe the biggest of my career,” she says. “Playing the home nation in front of a 50,000-plus crowd is going to create a very hostile atmosphere. We’re going to have to manage that.

“But there’s a lot of excitement around the camp. We’ve got great quality within this squad of 23 players. We’ve been building momentum and I think we’ve got better with each game. I’m hoping to take that momentum into the Canada game. I quite like having the feeling of having the crowd against us.

“It might give me a lift. It’s going to be a tough game but there’s a lot of pressure on Canada. They’ve been struggling to score goals so I think we can take advantage of that. We’ll have a gameplan to exploit it. We’re in the quarters now and we believe we can keep progressing.”

After giving birth to their twins only last autumn, Casey Stoney’s partner Megan Harris seems highly unlikely to make the long trek to Canada’s west coast – “we’ve decided to all go away and have a good holiday later this year,” says the England defender – but, like Chapman, Stoney has become a FaceTime regular.

Both women are looking forward to returning home – although not until after the denouement a week on Sunday. “If we could get to the final it would be unbelievable,” says Chapman. “It would be ‘oh my God’.”

cards.title: Everton / Club confirm £4.2m capture of Deulofeu from Barça
cards.rawTitle: Club confirm £4.2m capture of Deulofeu from Barça

item.title: Everton confirm £4.2m capture of Barcelona winger Gerard Deulofeu
item.trailText: Everton have confirmed the signing of the Barcelona winger Gerard Deulofeu, who was on loan at Goodison Park in 2013-14
item.standFirst:
• Deulofeu impressed on loan at Goodison Park during 2013-14 campaign
• 21-year-old was on loan at Sevilla last season but has signed three-year deal
item.body:
Everton have confirmed the signing of the Barcelona winger Gerard Deulofeu. The 21-year-old has signed a three-year-contract – with the option of a further year – in a deal worth £4.2m.

Related: Roberto Martínez and Everton revel as Gerard Deulofeu finds his feet

Deulofeu impressed on loan at Goodison Park in the 2013-14 campaign but returned to his parent club and was subsequently loaned out again to Sevilla.

He has long been touted as one of Barcelona’s next generation of stars but has failed to establish himself in first-team football either with the Catalan club or elsewhere and that is reflected in the price.

However, for that reason Barcelona have protected themselves against losing one of their brightest young talents by insisting on a release clause within the first two years if they meet certain conditions and having the right of first refusal if Everton decide to sell the player.

Roberto Martínez, who had a good relationship with Deulofeu, has kept tabs on his Spanish compatriot and the manager moved quickly to make him his second signing of the summer after capturing the out-of-contract Manchester United midfielder Tom Cleverley.

“Gerard needs no introduction to anyone here at Everton, for we are all well aware of his incredible footballing talent,” Martínez told evertonfc.com. “We got to know him really well from his loan period, not only as such a talented player but also his great character. He will be a fantastic asset to our club.”

displayImages.caption: Gerard Deulofeu made 29 appearances for Everton in the 2013-14 season, scoring four goals for Roberto Martínez's side. Photograph: Jan Kruger/Getty Images

cards.title: Bournemouth / Howe breaks transfer record to sign £8m Mings from Ipswich
cards.rawTitle: Howe breaks transfer record to sign £8m Mings from Ipswich

item.title: Bournemouth break transfer record to sign £8m Tyrone Mings from Ipswich
item.trailText: Bournemouth have broken their transfer record to sign Tyrone Mings from Ipswich Town in a deal worth more than £8m
item.standFirst:
• Exclusive: Aston Villa, Newcastle and West Brom also wanted player
• Winger Ryan Fraser will be loaned to Ipswich as part of the deal
item.body:
Bournemouth have broken their transfer record to sign Tyrone Mings from Ipswich Town in a deal believed to be worth £8m. Mings has agreed personal terms with the Premier League club after Bournemouth beat off competition from Aston Villa, West Bromwich Albion and Newcastle United and the left-back will sign a four-year contract at the Goldsands Stadium, subject to him passing a medical.

It is understood that Ryan Fraser, the former Aberdeen winger, is moving to Portman Road on loan as part of the deal. While there has been no shortage of interest in Mings, who cost Ipswich only £10,000 when they signed him from non-league Chippenham Town in December 2012, Bournemouth’s willingness to meet the Championship club’s valuation of the player propelled them to the front of queue.

Related: Tyrone Mings makes his mark at Ipswich on and off the pitch | Stuart James

Mings was given permission to talk to Bournemouth and travelled to the south coast on Wednesday night to hold talks with Eddie Howe on Thursday morning. He was hugely impressed with Howe and believes that the Bournemouth manager will help to develop his talent as part of the next step in a career that has gone from strength to strength ever since he gave up work as a mortgage adviser two and a half years ago.

Rejected by Southampton at the age of 16, Mings was turning out for Chippenham Town and driving a Citroën Saxo that cost him £100 when Ipswich offered him a trial in December 2012. Mick McCarthy, the Ipswich manager, liked what he saw and the five-figure sum the Championship club paid Chippenham for Mings must rank as one of their best investments.

Mings, who is 6ft 5in, blessed with a good left foot and is a fine athlete, blossomed under McCarthy’s watch and attracted attention from leading Premier League clubs, including Arsenal and Chelsea, where his father, Adie, works as a scout. Crystal Palace had a £3m bid for Mings rejected last September and the player’s value continued to climb during a season in which Ipswich reached the play-off semi-finals before losing to Norwich.

Howe has watched Mings’s progress closely and the Bournemouth board backed his judgment to make a move for a player who was coveted by a number of their top-flight rivals only for them to be discouraged by the price put on his head.

As well as catching the eye with his performances on the pitch at Portman Road, Mings has picked up a reputation for being something of a good Samaritan in the world of football, with various gestures of goodwill, including one act of kindness that made him national news before he had made his debut for Ipswich.

In March 2013 Mings exchanged tweets with an Ipswich supporter who could not afford to go their home match against Bolton because he was “skint”. Mings replied on Twitter and said that he would leave his complimentary tickets at Portman Road for the fan to collect. The exchange between the two went viral.

In an interview with the Guardian in December, Mings talked about how much enjoyment he got from spending Christmas Day in 2013 feeding the homeless in Ipswich. The following summer he paid for some replacement replica shirts for supporters who were frustrated when his squad number changed from No15 to No3 and in April this year it emerged that he had cleared his mother’s debts.

cards.title: Sepp Blatter / Fifa president’s attendance at Women’s World Cup final in doubt
cards.rawTitle: Fifa president’s attendance at Women’s World Cup final in doubt

item.title: Fifa president Sepp Blatter’s attendance at Women’s World Cup final in doubt
item.trailText: Sepp Blatter’s attendance at the Women’s World Cup final in Canada next week appears to be in jeopardy due to the twin investigations into Fifa by American and Swiss justice authorities
item.standFirst:
• Blatter is due to present trophy at final in Vancouver
• Fifa spokesman would not confirm if president will travel to Canada
item.body:
Sepp Blatter’s attendance at the Women’s World Cup final in Canada next week appears to be in jeopardy due to the twin investigations into Fifa by American and Swiss justice authorities.

Blatter would normally attend the final and hand over the trophy to the captain of the winning team but Fifa will not confirm whether he or the secretary general, Jérôme Valcke, will attend.

A spokesperson said: “In terms of the Fifa president and the Fifa secretary general, their future travel plans will be confirmed in due course.”

Related: Russians expect Sepp Blatter to attend 2018 World Cup qualifying draw

Reports in the United States have said Blatter and Valcke are among those under investigation by the FBI, which has so far indicted 18 people on football-related corruption charges.

A source close to Fifa said the crisis is having a bearing over whether Blatter travels to Canada. The Swiss attorney general is also investigating the bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups.

Neither the president nor secretary general have been charged with any wrongdoing and the US has not requested Blatter’s or Valcke’s extradition. Should that change, as a Swiss national Blatter is protected from extradition from Switzerland by Article 7 of IMAC, the governing Swiss law.

The Russian sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, has said Blatter will attend the 2018 World Cup qualifying draw in St Petersburg on 25 July.

“Of course, he will attend the draw,” Mutko said on Tuesday. “The whole of the Fifa executive committee will be there as well as all 209 national federations. Preparations are going as planned.”

displayImages.caption: A Fifa spokesman would not confirm if Sepp Blatter will travel to Canada. Photograph: Ruben Sprich/REUTERS

cards.title: Manchester United / We can challenge for the title next season, says Rooney
cards.rawTitle: We can challenge for the title next season, says Rooney

item.title: Wayne Rooney: Manchester United can challenge for the title next season
item.trailText: Wayne Rooney believes Manchester United can challenge for the Premier League title next season, although the England captain has admitted that Louis van Gaal’s squad will need strengthening
item.standFirst:
• ‘With a couple of signings we will have a good chance of doing that’
• England captain pleased to avoid ‘disaster’ of not finishing in top four
item.body:
Wayne Rooney believes Manchester United can challenge for the Premier League title next season, although the England captain has admitted that Louis van Gaal’s squad will need strengthening if they are to climb the table.

Related: Liverpool one of two English clubs interested in signing Carlos Bacca

After finishing seventh in 2013/14 under David Moyes, United again got off to a slow start last season despite the arrival of Van Gaal, recording just three wins from their first 10 matches. Their form improved considerably after Christmas as the Dutchman guided United to a fourth-placed finish.

Now Rooney is hoping they can build on that momentum and challenge at the top for the first time since winning their 20th title in 2012/13.

“I honestly believe we will go far next year and won’t be far off challenging for the league,” Rooney said.

“If you look at the first 10 to 11 games we only had around 13 points, and if you look at where we finished I think it shows we could have been up there with a better start. We’ve dominated and outplayed most teams this season but haven’t taken our chances to win those games, it could have been a different story if we had.

“The most important thing is that as a squad, including the manager and myself, we believe we are close to challenging for the title and with a couple of signings we will have a good chance of doing that.

“It would be good to win as many cups as possible, a club like Manchester United should be winning trophies and hopefully next season we can put that right.”

Rooney added: “Our main target this year was to get back into the top four, and we have done that so in that sense it’s not bad at all.

“You have to realise that at the start of the season we had a new manager, new coaches and a lot of new players, so it was always going to be a tough ask for us to go and win the Premier League.

“It was a bit disappointing not to win any silverware, especially the FA Cup after the defeat to Arsenal in the quarter-finals; we had a great chance of going on to win that.

“After last season it would have been a disaster if we didn’t get that Champions League spot, but the main thing is that the club is now back where it belongs.”

displayImages.caption: Wayne Rooney believes Manchester United can improve on last season's fourth place. Photograph: Peter Powell/EPA

cards.title: Manchester City / Club close in on Bursaspor’s highly-rated striker Unal
cards.rawTitle: Club close in on Bursaspor’s highly-rated striker Unal

item.title: Manchester City close in on Bursaspor’s coveted striker Enes Unal
item.trailText: Bursaspor have given their highly-rated striker Enes Unal permission to travel to England to discuss a possible deal with Manchester City
item.standFirst:
• Bursaspor allow 18-year-old to travel to England to discuss possible deal
• ‘An agreement in principle has been reached,’ says player’s agent
item.body:
Bursaspor have given their highly-rated striker Enes Unal permission to travel to England to discuss a possible deal with Manchester City.

The 18-year-old, who won his first senior cap for Turkey in the 2-1 victory against Luxembourg in March, is likely to command a fee of around £500,000.

The Bursaspor president, Recep Bolukbasi, said on Thursday that they had reached an agreement with City and that he thought the transfer would go through at the weekend.

Related: Next Generation 2014: 40 of the best young talents in world football

The player’s agent, Batur Altiparmak, added: “An agreement in principle has been reached. Bursaspor have given Unal permission to have a medical at Manchester City.”

Unal would become the first Turkish player to join Manchester City should the deal go ahead and the youngest Super Lig player to move to the Premier League. Bursaspor have a reputation for developing forwards and recently sold the 19-year-old striker Batuhan Altıntas to Hamburg for £350,000.

Unal had an extraordinary goal ratio at youth level, attracting scouts from across Europe after scoring 182 goals in 110 appearances for Bursaspor’s reserves. He also struck 24 times in 25 international games for Turkey at under-16 level before being fast-tracked into the under-19 and under-21 sides.

The City target also became the youngest player, aged 16, to score in the Super Lig when he netted against Galatasaray on 1 August 2013. Unal has a total of seven first–team goals to his name for the Bursaspor and scored once every 197 minutes of league football last season.

Emre Sarigul is the editor of Turkish Football. Follow him on Twitter here.

displayImages.caption: Enes Unal attracted attention after scoring 182 goals in 110 appearances for Bursaspor reserves and now looks set to join Manchester City. Photograph: Lino Arrigo Azzopardi/EPA/Corbis
